sn45.48:0.2.eng: 5. Abbreviated Texts on Followers of Other Religions

sn45.48:0.3.eng: Extinguishment With No Fuel For Grasping

sn45.48:1.2.pli: “Sace vo, bhikkhave, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṃ puccheyyuṃ:
sn45.48:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, if wanderers who follow another religion were to ask you:

sn45.48:1.3.pli: ‘kimatthiyaṃ, āvuso, samaṇe gotame brahmacariyaṃ vussatī’ti, evaṃ puṭṭhā tumhe, bhikkhave, tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ evaṃ byākareyyātha:
sn45.48:1.3.eng: ‘Reverends, what’s the purpose of leading the spiritual life under the ascetic Gotama?’ You should answer them like this:

sn45.48:1.4.eng: ‘The purpose of leading the spiritual life under the Buddha is complete extinguishment with no fuel for grasping.’

sn45.48:1.5.pli: Sace pana vo, bhikkhave, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṃ puccheyyuṃ:
sn45.48:1.5.eng: If wanderers of other religions were to ask you:

sn45.48:1.6.pli: ‘atthi panāvuso, maggo, atthi paṭipadā anupādāparinibbānāyā’ti, evaṃ puṭṭhā tumhe, bhikkhave, tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ evaṃ byākareyyātha:
sn45.48:1.6.eng: ‘Is there a path and a practice for complete extinguishment with no fuel for grasping?’ You should answer them like this:

sn45.48:1.7.pli: ‘atthi kho, āvuso, maggo, atthi paṭipadā anupādāparinibbānāyā’ti.
sn45.48:1.7.eng: ‘There is a path and a practice for complete extinguishment with no fuel for grasping.’

sn45.48:1.8.pli: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, maggo, katamā ca paṭipadā anupādāparinibbānāya?
sn45.48:1.8.eng: And what is that path, what is that practice for complete extinguishment with no fuel for grasping?

sn45.48:1.9.eng: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn45.48:1.10.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn45.48:1.11.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, maggo, ayaṃ paṭipadā anupādāparinibbānāyāti.
sn45.48:1.11.eng: This is the path, this is the practice for complete extinguishment with no fuel for grasping.

sn45.48:1.12.pli: Evaṃ puṭṭhā tumhe, bhikkhave, tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ evaṃ byākareyyāthā”ti.
sn45.48:1.12.eng: When questioned by wanderers of other religions, that’s how you should answer them.”

sn45.49:1.2.pli: “Sūriyassa, bhikkhave, udayato etaṃ pubbaṅgamaṃ etaṃ pubbanimittaṃ, yadidaṃ—aruṇuggaṃ;
sn45.49:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, the dawn is the forerunner and precursor of the sunrise.

sn45.49:1.3.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno ariyassa aṭṭhaṅgikassa maggassa uppādāya etaṃ pubbaṅgamaṃ etaṃ pubbanimittaṃ, yadidaṃ—kalyāṇamittatā.
sn45.49:1.3.eng: In the same way good friendship is the forerunner and precursor of the noble eightfold path for a mendicant.

sn45.49:1.4.pli: Kalyāṇamittassetaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno pāṭikaṅkhaṃ—ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāvessati, ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bahulīkarissati.
sn45.49:1.4.eng: A mendicant with good friends can expect to develop and cultivate the noble eightfold path.

sn45.49:1.5.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kalyāṇamitto ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāveti, ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bahulīkaroti?
sn45.49:1.5.eng: And how does a mendicant with good friends develop and cultivate the noble eightfold path?

sn45.49:1.6.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sammādiṭṭhiṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ …pe… sammāsamādhiṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ.
sn45.49:1.6.eng: It’s when a mendicant develops right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion, which rely on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripen as letting go.

sn45.49:1.7.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kalyāṇamitto ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāveti, ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bahulīkarotī”ti.
sn45.49:1.7.eng: That’s how a mendicant with good friends develops and cultivates the noble eightfold path.”

sn45.5:1.2.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu …pe… ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn45.5:1.2.eng: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha … and said to him:

sn45.5:2.1.pli: “Idha no, bhante, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā amhe evaṃ pucchanti:
sn45.5:2.1.eng: “Sir, sometimes wanderers of other religions ask us:

sn45.5:2.2.eng: ‘Reverends, what’s the purpose of leading the spiritual life under the ascetic Gotama?’

sn45.5:2.3.pli: Evaṃ puṭṭhā mayaṃ, bhante, tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ evaṃ byākaroma:

sn45.5:2.4.pli: ‘dukkhassa kho, āvuso, pariññatthaṃ bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatī’ti.
sn45.5:2.4.eng: ‘The purpose of leading the spiritual life under the Buddha is to completely understand suffering.’

sn45.5:2.5.pli: Kacci mayaṃ, bhante, evaṃ puṭṭhā evaṃ byākaramānā vuttavādino ceva bhagavato homa, na ca bhagavantaṃ abhūtena abbhācikkhāma, dhammassa cānudhammaṃ byākaroma, na ca koci sahadhammiko vādānuvādo gārayhaṃ ṭhānaṃ āgacchatī”ti?
sn45.5:2.5.eng: Answering this way, we trust that we repeat what the Buddha has said, and don’t misrepresent him with an untruth. We trust our explanation is in line with the teaching, and that there are no legitimate grounds for rebuttal or criticism.”

sn45.5:3.1.pli: “Taggha tumhe, bhikkhave, evaṃ puṭṭhā evaṃ byākaramānā vuttavādino ceva me hotha, na ca maṃ abhūtena abbhācikkhatha, dhammassa cānudhammaṃ byākarotha, na ca koci sahadhammiko vādānuvādo gārayhaṃ ṭhānaṃ āgacchati.
sn45.5:3.1.eng: “Indeed, in answering this way you repeat what I’ve said, and don’t misrepresent me with an untruth. Your explanation is in line with the teaching, and there are no legitimate grounds for rebuttal or criticism.

sn45.5:3.2.pli: Dukkhassa hi pariññatthaṃ mayi brahmacariyaṃ vussati.
sn45.5:3.2.eng: For the purpose of leading the spiritual life under me is to completely understand suffering.

sn45.5:3.3.pli: Sace vo, bhikkhave, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṃ puccheyyuṃ:
sn45.5:3.3.eng: If wanderers of other religions were to ask you:

sn45.5:3.4.pli: ‘atthi panāvuso, maggo, atthi paṭipadā etassa dukkhassa pariññāyā’ti, evaṃ puṭṭhā tumhe, bhikkhave, tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ evaṃ byākareyyātha:
sn45.5:3.4.eng: ‘Is there a path and a practice for completely understanding that suffering?’ You should answer them like this:

sn45.5:3.5.pli: ‘atthi kho, āvuso, maggo, atthi paṭipadā etassa dukkhassa pariññāyā’ti.

sn45.5:4.1.pli: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, maggo, katamā paṭipadā etassa dukkhassa pariññāyāti?

sn45.5:4.2.eng: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn45.5:4.3.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn45.5:4.4.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, maggo, ayaṃ paṭipadā etassa dukkhassa pariññāyāti.
sn45.5:4.4.eng: This is the path and the practice for completely understanding suffering.

sn45.5:4.5.pli: Evaṃ puṭṭhā tumhe, bhikkhave, tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ evaṃ byākareyyāthā”ti.
sn45.5:4.5.eng: When questioned by wanderers of other religions, that’s how you should answer them.”

sn45.6:1.2.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn45.6:1.2.eng: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha … and asked him,

sn45.6:1.3.eng: “Sir, they speak of this thing called the ‘spiritual path’.

sn45.6:1.4.pli: Katamaṃ nu kho, bhante, brahmacariyaṃ, katamaṃ brahmacariyapariyosānan”ti?
sn45.6:1.4.eng: What is the spiritual path? And what is the culmination of the spiritual path?”

sn45.6:2.1.pli: “Ayameva kho, bhikkhu, ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo brahmacariyaṃ, seyyathidaṃ—
sn45.6:2.1.eng: “Mendicant, the spiritual path is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn45.6:2.2.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn45.6:2.3.pli: Yo kho, bhikkhu, rāgakkhayo dosakkhayo mohakkhayo—
sn45.6:2.3.eng: The ending of greed, hate, and delusion.

sn45.6:2.4.eng: This is the culmination of the spiritual path.”

sn45.7:2.4.eng: “Mendicant, the removal of greed, hate, and delusion is a term for the element of extinguishment.

sn45.7:2.6.eng: It’s used to speak of the ending of defilements.”

sn45.7:3.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn45.7:3.1.eng: When he said this, the mendicant said to the Buddha:

sn45.7:3.3.pli: Katamaṃ nu kho, bhante, amataṃ, katamo amatagāmimaggo”ti?
sn45.7:3.3.eng: What is freedom from death? And what is the path that leads to freedom from death?”

sn45.7:3.4.eng: “The ending of greed, hate, and delusion.

sn45.7:3.5.eng: This is called freedom from death.

sn45.7:3.6.pli: Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo amatagāmimaggo, seyyathidaṃ—
sn45.7:3.6.eng: The path that leads to freedom from death is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn45.7:3.7.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.”

sn45.70:1.2.pli: “Ekadhammo, bhikkhave, bahūpakāro ariyassa aṭṭhaṅgikassa maggassa uppādāya.
sn45.70:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, one thing helps give rise to the noble eightfold path.

sn45.70:1.5.pli: Kalyāṇamittassetaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno pāṭikaṅkhaṃ—ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāvessati, ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bahulīkarissati.
sn45.70:1.5.eng: A mendicant with good friends can expect to develop and cultivate the noble eightfold path.

sn45.70:1.6.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kalyāṇamitto ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāveti, ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bahulīkaroti?
sn45.70:1.6.eng: And how does a mendicant with good friends develop and cultivate the noble eightfold path?

sn45.70:1.7.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sammādiṭṭhiṃ bhāveti rāgavinayapariyosānaṃ dosavinayapariyosānaṃ mohavinayapariyosānaṃ …pe… sammāsamādhiṃ bhāveti rāgavinayapariyosānaṃ dosavinayapariyosānaṃ mohavinayapariyosānaṃ.
sn45.70:1.7.eng: It’s when a mendicant develops right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion, which culminate in the removal of greed, hate, and delusion.

sn45.70:1.8.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kalyāṇamitto ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāveti, ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bahulīkarotī”ti.
sn45.70:1.8.eng: That’s how a mendicant with good friends develops and cultivates the noble eightfold path.”

sn45.71-75:0.3.eng: Five Discourses on Accomplishment in Ethics, Etc. (2nd)

sn45.71-75:1.2.pli: “Ekadhammo, bhikkhave, bahūpakāro ariyassa aṭṭhaṅgikassa maggassa uppādāya.
sn45.71-75:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, one thing helps give rise to the noble eightfold path.

sn45.76:0.3.eng: Accomplishment in Rational Application of Mind (2nd)

sn45.76:1.1.eng: “… accomplishment in rational application of mind.

sn45.76:1.2.pli: Yonisomanasikārasampannassetaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno pāṭikaṅkhaṃ—ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāvessati, ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bahulīkarissati.
sn45.76:1.2.eng: A mendicant accomplished in rational application of mind can expect to develop and cultivate the noble eightfold path.

sn45.76:1.3.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yonisomanasikārasampanno ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāveti, ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bahulīkaroti?
sn45.76:1.3.eng: And how does a mendicant accomplished in rational application of mind develop and cultivate the noble eightfold path?

sn45.76:1.4.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sammādiṭṭhiṃ bhāveti …pe… sammāsamādhiṃ bhāveti rāgavinayapariyosānaṃ dosavinayapariyosānaṃ mohavinayapariyosānaṃ.
sn45.76:1.4.eng: It’s when a mendicant develops right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion, which culminate in the removal of greed, hate, and delusion.

sn45.76:1.5.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yonisomanasikārasampanno ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāveti, ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bahulīkarotī”ti.
sn45.76:1.5.eng: That’s how a mendicant accomplished in rational application of mind develops and cultivates the noble eightfold path.”

sn45.77:1.2.pli: “Nāhaṃ, bhikkhave, aññaṃ ekadhammampi samanupassāmi, yena anuppanno vā ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo uppajjati, uppanno vā ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchati, yathayidaṃ, bhikkhave, kalyāṇamittatā.
sn45.77:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I do not see a single thing that gives rise to the noble eightfold path, or, if it’s already arisen, fully develops it like good friendship.

sn45.77:1.3.pli: Kalyāṇamittassetaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno pāṭikaṅkhaṃ—ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāvessati, ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bahulīkarissati.
sn45.77:1.3.eng: A mendicant with good friends can expect to develop and cultivate the noble eightfold path.

sn45.77:1.4.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kalyāṇamitto ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāveti, ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bahulīkaroti?
sn45.77:1.4.eng: And how does a mendicant with good friends develop and cultivate the noble eightfold path?

sn45.77:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sammādiṭṭhiṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ …pe… sammāsamādhiṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ.
sn45.77:1.5.eng: It’s when a mendicant develops right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion, which rely on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripen as letting go.

sn45.77:1.6.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kalyāṇamitto ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāveti, ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bahulīkarotī”ti.
sn45.77:1.6.eng: That’s how a mendicant with good friends develops and cultivates the noble eightfold path.”

sn45.78-82:0.3.eng: Five Discourses on Accomplishment in Ethics, Etc.

sn45.78-82:1.1.pli: “Nāhaṃ, bhikkhave, aññaṃ ekadhammampi samanupassāmi, yena anuppanno vā ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo uppajjati, uppanno vā ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchati, yathayidaṃ, bhikkhave, sīlasampadā …pe…
sn45.78-82:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I do not see a single thing that gives rise to the noble eightfold path, or, if it’s already arisen, fully develops it like accomplishment in ethics. …”
